story:
Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) is a very rare cancer tumor. It is a rare neoplasm of the dermis layer of the skin, and is classified as a sarcoma. It is extremely rare and little known or written about - being told youre one case per million per year doesn’t help the anxiety and worry levels and there is little support to rely on. You cannot google as there is little feedback and so you learn as you fight.

I attended Southmead Hospital in Bristol to have my tumour removed after smaller investigatory operations had been attempted and the treatment that day and every check up since has been amazing.

The support I had from family and friends was also amazing and I was determined to fight and to not label the tunour as cancer - it was a tumour and it was going!

Today we hit the 5 year anniversary of its removal and even though the world is fighting a pandemic, daily worries about furlough and employment and immense worry about those close - I survived and for that I am so so grateful. Good luck to all those who are still fighting - be one in a million in a positive way x

story:
Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. 

Lucinda, my wife had a sudden heart attack in early December 2020 and was brilliantly looked after by the NHS; and the knowledge of her rare SCAD condition through research from bodies such as the British Heart Foundation have made a material difference to her recovery, and the recovery of many thousands of others.

I have decided to gather a group of ten good friends and do ten brilliant rides throughout the early part of 2021 to try and raise £1,000 a day. I am putting in £900 and hoping my friends will put in at least £100 to join me. It will either be a 50 kilometre mountain bike ride or a 100 kilometres on the road. I look forward to a lot of fun miles, some good friendships and raising fantastic funds for a brilliant cause!

Thank you, Robert Langmead

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
The last 12 months have been tough on everyone,  so many charities have been unable to find raise in traditional ways and funding for vital research has suffered. 

People that know me will tell you how much of a chocoholic I am. I don’t drink coffee so chocolate is what gets me through the day! This will be a huge personal challenge and I hope you will help to motivate me with a donation towards this excellent charity. 

From the British Heart Foundation:

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

story:
Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation as I have various heart conditions that many people wouldnt know I had, to look at me you would assume I am normal.

I actually have a VSD which is a hole in the heart on a valve in simple language. What this means to me is I can't over exhert myself as it would mean I struggle to breathe... this I have lived with since birth. It has taken me years to work out what I can and can't do and the reasons why I can't do certain things... it lead to anxiety attacks through fear of not being able to do things. Only by growing up with this have I learnt the effects and ways to control it.

So to go along side this (as if its not enough) I have an irregular heartbeat, thickened heart wall and a heart murmur. I go for check ups once every 5 years so nothing major, but I have always had them at its always at the back of my mind when doing anything.

So thats my reasoning, due to lockdown I have had to give up football again a huge passion of mine but have found that I enjoy running and wanted to set myself a challenge... hence this and I thought let's do it for a good cause.

The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. story:
In March 1973  I underwent, what was at the time, pioneering surgery. I was born with hole in the heart. By the time I was 15 the wall of the chamber had collapsed and i was admitted as an emergency. I was lucky. Had it been as little as 10 years previous I wouldn't have survived as it was I needed 32 pints of blood. I owe my life not only to the fantastic surgeon but to BHF without their research medical advancement would not be made. They are now able to perform the same operation on tiny babies with huge success, and because of the advance in technology, only a fraction of the amount of blood is required.

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to the BHF being forced to make the devastating decision to cut their research budget in half. So the truth is, they've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help  keep up the pace of progress. story:
To raise as much money as possible for the British Heart Foundation, I’m taking part in the Dechox challenge, meaning no chocolate for the whole of March!

As some might know, my grandma recently passed away due to a heart condition, and I know that many others have been in a similar situation. Due to Covid, fundraising efforts have fallen, with charity shops being closed and events being cancelled.

Thank you

story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

story:
Hello,

I'm sure the majority of you know who I am, but for those that don't know me...

I am Lizzie (25yrs), girlfriend to Ben and mummy to Sienna.  I have a questionable relationship with chocolate, it's either a whole share bar or nothing type of thing.  If you know me well, you'll be reading this and thinking "she's going to struggle doing this", and the answer is YES I AM but here's why I'm doing it.

My Daddy unfortunately passed away on 1st March 2014  whilst my family and I were on a skiing holiday in France.  This was about 3 weeks after his 59th birthday.  He suffered from a ruptured dissecting thoracic aortic aneurysm (a mouthful, I know).  I would be surprised if you knew what that is so there's a link at the bottom for more info.  One day he was here, the next morning he was gone.  He left a massive hole in everyone's lives that knew him, especially mine.  He was my hero, my best friend but most of all my Daddy.  After 7 years I still can't believe he's gone.

I haven't done anything charity wise for him since he died as I haven't managed to pluck up the courage to share my story.  It's never something I've spoken about to anyone.  2021 feels like the right year to be brave and jump into something crazy (for me that is).  

Any donations or even messages of support would be massively appreciated.  I really want to raise awareness about my story and help British Heart Foundation in their research of heart and circulatory diseases.

Lots of love

Lizzie xx

P.S Thank you very much in advance  

https://www.bhf.org.uk/informationsupport/conditions/aortic-aneurysm

story:
2020 was a hard year, I did dechox last year, just as the pandemic was hitting and I managed it, but since then my chocolate addiction has crept back in and probably gone worse than ever, being at home does not help! This year it is not only chocolate I am dechoxing from though, I am also going for sweets (I have signed up for the level 3 dechox challenge which is chocolate, sweets and fizzy drinks but I don't drink fizzy drinks anyway), I am 100% positive I will find this even harder than normal as when I don't have choc I tend to switch to sweets! 

In June 2020 I lost my Dad too, primarily due to a stroke but secondarily due to heart disease he suffered from angina for a good 20 years and while in hospital following his stroke he suffered multiple heart attacks. 

The British Heart Foundation still play a part in when it comes to strokes too as it is the restriction of blood to parts of the brain that cause a stroke. Maintaining a healthy weight, which in my case dechox can play a part in along with Slimming World, can help lower the risk of strokes and heart attacks.

I am due to get married in September too and have a wedding dress to get into, Dechox and Slimming World together are going to get me closer to fitting in that dress!

If I can raise a few quid for BHF then this is a challenge I will hit head on, you may find me rocking in a corner by end of march though...be ready with the Easter Eggs!

story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

story:
Me and Dale are both doing this to help raise money for this important charity. Dale’s wonderful dad Glyn passed away due to heart problems in 2018. It was devastatingly unexpected and sadly this is the reality for many families. The Dechox challenge is very simple and a great way to help raise money that the British Heart Foundation so desperately need. We are taking on the level 3 challenge of giving up chocolate, sweets and fizzy drinks. We have also decided we want to make it more of a challenge and we will be giving up alcohol too, and commit to being as healthy as we possibly can be. We will be eating healthy, exercising and adhering to a strict diet and have agreed that we will donate £1 for every pound we loose before the end of March on top of our current donations. We want to raise as much as we can in memory of Glyn. £150 is a small target but we are hoping to smash that and move the target up as we go. The BHF help so many families that go through awful times and provide care and support for those that need it, while also putting every effort into groundbreaking research to save millions of lives. 


We are grateful to anyone that is able to donate any amount, especially when we are all suffering from this pandemic. If anyone also wants to take part in the Dechox challenge you can sign up through the BHF website or the following link; https://www.bhf.org.uk/how-you-can-help/fundraise/dechox/register/get-started 


The pandemic is the biggest challenge British Heart Foundation have faced in their 60 year history. And it's led to them being forced to make the devastating decision to cut the 2020 research budget in half. They have never needed people to pull together more and help raise these vital funds. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help them keep up the pace of progress. Despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

Guide Dogs is here to help solve this problem. We provide individual support that overcomes the emotional and physical challenges faced by people living with sight loss.

story:
Ryan’s story


In late 2018, I was diagnosed with a very rare vascular disease called Leukocytoclastic Vasculitis, this is a disease that is quite unknown and is described as “1 in a million” by health experts. 

This disease makes the immune system overwork and attacks healthy blood vessels in my body causing them to inflame and come out in a rash, it also attacks vital organs in the body, like the kidneys. 

In February 2019, I was admitted to Great Ormond Street Hospital, I underwent a series of intense testing for nearly a week and I cannot thank the nurses and doctors and everyone at Great Ormond Street. I would especially like to thank the wonderful, hardworking, cheerful and caring nurses that looked after me that week in the rheumatoid department, even though I felt very ill and I was struggling. The nurses were like shining lights when looking after me. 

Finally, with everything going on at the moment and NHS staff not getting what they deserve or recognition of their hard work battling on the frontlines to save our lives from COVID-19, the least me and Lucy could do is raise a bit of money to help out. 

So please donate what you can to a wonderful cause that means absolutely everything to me and my family.

We will give updates regularly on our social media accounts to let you know how we are getting on. 

All donations would be appreciated. Thank you very much for all of your support. 


Ryan Baldwin and Lucy Kirby.

story:
After sadly losing our Grandpa to cancer in August, I decided I wanted to set myself a challenge & complete it in memory of him. After lots of deliberation of what I should do, I decided to go for running 150km in 30 days (5k a day). Wanting it to sound more impressive I whatsapped my sister (Rosie) and roped her in! After a bit of convincing and debating how far we should run, we settled on 150km each & are both determined to complete the 300km together to make him proud. 

He was a very active man himself, cycling all over the world, bodyboarding in the freezing cornish seas and would regularly go on runs in his Nike Air Max's that he was very proud of (so trendy!) We will be running thinking about him and all the amazing memories we had together!

The challenge commenced on the 11th of January and ends on the 9th of February. We really appreciate any donations and kind messages you send, thank you x

Thanks for taking the time to visit Elizabeth Muscutt's Cancer Research JustGiving page.

As I'm sure you will be aware Elizabeth (Mum) fought cancer for some time. She won a first round of bowel cancer and had been given the chance to return to normal life. We were shocked when we found it had returned ~20 years later.

And while we are all sad that she has lost her second battle with Cancer we must remember what she was able to do in those years since.....

See her son, Chris get married; see all her grandchildren born and growing up; watch Lisa benefiting from her double lung transplant and going to a transplant games; and of course be with her husband Bill and Mother Frances until the end. 

All those that know Elizabeth know she was a true saint. She always worried & cared for others and we could see this through so many things she did. story:
Every day of your life matters from the first to the last. We believe that everyone living with a terminal illness should be able to get the most from the time they have left, however hard that may sometimes feel. 
We'll be here for you and your family when you may feel like no-one else is, to help you cope when you don't know how. Marie Curie Nurses care for you in your home, when you need them most, day or night. Our hospices are at the heart of communities around the UK. And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk. 
We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

story:
I started running during lockdown just for something to do and to stay active, my friend decided it would be a good idea to run 5 Ultra marathons in 5 days running 300km from Galway to Wicklow, Being my competitive impulsive self I thought I'd sign up too.

In October my Mum was diagnosed with incurable Cancer, or to be more precise several incurable cancers, however for those of you who our privileged to have met my Mum, you know how stubborn she is, how strong she allows her faith to carry her through sickness, how she gives people strength and hope even in the darkest of times, how she finds joy, happiness and thankfulness when others cant, and how she will always put others first before seeing to herself.

After the diagnoses and coming to terms with the reality of what Mum is facing, I decided to use my run to fundraise for the Marie Curie foundation, to help contribute to the amazing nurses and personnel that help, comfort and guide patients with Cancer.

Every time I now lace up the shoes and hit the road, I now think of all the amazing memories I've had with my mum, in awe of her magnificence, of everything she has done for me and others and continues to do. My running now has a different purpose, and although completing 5 ultra marathons in 5 days my seem crazily unnecessary, its absolutely nothing in relation to what my Mum and other Cancer patients endure, and for that I'll put one foot in front of the other.



All we have to decide is what to do with the time that is given us.


No matter how small the donation, I will be eternally thankful for your support.

charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
A number of years ago I first started cycling by signing up to a London to Paris charity cycle where I met David Bradford who is now a good friend of mine. Through David I met his son Adam and did a Wiggle event in France with them. Unfortunately Adam was diagnosed with a brain tumour and sadly passed away in December of 2019. Through his last few weeks he was cared for by the Marie Curie Hospice team in Newcastle and it seems the right charity to donate all of the money raised for this event as one close to Adam's family and for the support that they gave Adam until the end.

Some details of the hospice are below....

We're here to support people with serious illnesses in the Newcastle area to have the best quality of life possible, whatever that might mean for them. Our hospice team includes doctors, nurses, physiotherapists, social workers and many more, and is supported by over 100 volunteers, who play a vital role in the running of the hospice. Some people stay in our 20-bed in-patient unit, where relatives and friends can visit any time of the day or night, and stay with their loved ones if they wish. Our day therapy unit offers outpatient clinics and a wide range of activities and therapies, including baking, art therapy and relaxation. We also provide support for carers and families, including our social work team who provide emotional and practical advice. Our chaplain is here to provide spiritual care to patients and their loved ones. Thank you for supporting us, and helping to make sure more people with a terminal illness in the Newcastle area get the care and support they need.

story:
Thank you for visiting our page. Our demand is higher than usual with our lifeboats and lifeguard responding to more calls for help than ever before.

Our volunteer crews are on call 24 hours a day, 365 days a year, on average saving 26 lives a day! 

We would usually be welcoming you at our fundraising events, talking about the work of the RNLI but due to Covid many of these events continue to be cancelled.  

This is having a huge effect on donations which is why we are coming out to our friends, families and supporters virtually to ask for your help - we rely on donations from you the general public and without your support we wouldn't be able to continue saving lives at sea.

The pandemic of 2020 and into 2021 has brought a new risk to our volunteers that we never could have predicted or imagined but our brave and courageous crew members continue to risk their lives to save others.

We hope that you can support us by donating on our page - we look forward to seeing you soon, stay safe.

story:
Welcome to the RNLI Felixstowe Fundraising Branch Fundraising Page.

Felixstowe is a large container port and many Felixstowe residents are connected with the  sea so we are very aware of the need for support for the RNLI. 

The sea around Felixstowe is served by RNLI lifeboats based just across the water in Harwich. The last few months been very busy with the number of launches made by our crews.

The RNLI rely on public donations to keep their fleet running. Your local Felixstowe Fundraising Branch has continued to raise vital funds, as far as possible, under the current restrictions. 

Like most charities the RNLI have had to make changes to their fundraising during 2020 and 2021 with the restrictions posed by Covid 19.

Whilst it is possible to donate to the RNLI nationally, we have been asked to provide an on-line donation facility for our supporters that have been missing walks into town and unable to donate as they usually do to our collections.

charity.name: WWF-UK
story:
Please join myself and WWF in The Big Winter Wander.

Head outdoors and get closer with nature on your doorstep. In the UK alone, we have lost 50% of wildlife populations such as our stunning red squirrel, hedgehogs and garden birds. 

So it's time to give something back to nature, as you all know 2020 was a strange year that left us all guessing what was going to happen next but in that time the great outdoors became a place of solidarity and refugee. 

As we all know, being outdoors not only enables us to engage with our local green or blue space but provides stability and worthiness regarding our mental health and well-being. 

Charities such as WWF provide wildlife a chance on a local and global basis. 

How could your money help: 

£50: could pay for a marine pinger to be used on fishing nets to prevent any form of marine mammal bycatch. 

£100: could pay for a farmer to plant and protect 35 native trees on their land, enabling areas of the farm to be rewilded. 

£300: could pay to sow over 3,000 wildflowers that bear nectar to provide food for our essential pollinating insects. 

All funds go directly to WWF to help conserve, protect and monitor wildlife on a global basis!

story:
Thanks for supporting my 400k @ 40 fundraiser for UNICEF. 

This March, I turn 40, and as I’m not going to be able to have a big party, I thought I’d try and do something productive instead. So, in an attempt to battle the challenges of middle age without buying a motorbike, I thought that setting up a running challenge would be a positive thing to do.

The challenge I have set myself is to run 400km over the course of 2021. This will mostly be little and often - trying to do two or three 5km runs a week, but maybe I’ll get really into it and sign up for a half marathon or something (no promises)! 

My fundraising page is part of a wider fundraiser called Chase The Majors (also raising funds for UNICEF), so I will have plenty of company as I try to remain on track.
